awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: An Enzyme-free Amplification Technique for Ultrasensitive ELISA of Disease Biomarkers
awd_abstract_narration:
Technologies for diagnosis of diseases are essential to the improvement of our standard of living. Increasing detection sensitivity of a diagnostic technology can enable earlier diagnosis of diseases especially cancers and infectious diseases, thus improving treatment outcomes. The goal of this project is to establish a highly sensitive diagnostic platform through the development of a nanoparticle-based signal amplification technique. The broader impacts of the proposed research program include multidisciplinary training for graduate and undergraduate students particularly from underrepresented groups, as well as outreach activities such as mentoring local high-school students and student exchange between two institutes in summer.



Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) technology has been extensively used in research labs and clinical diagnostics for decades. However, its limit of detection has not been substantially improved in recent years. The proposed work seeks to develop a novel enzyme-free signal amplification technique that can substantially enhance the detection sensitivity of ELISA. This technique relies on the release of millions of tiny nanoparticles preloaded in gold vesicles. Each released nanoparticle can catalyze colorimetric reaction more effectively than a commonly-used enzyme in an ELISA. By substituting enzymes in a conventional ELISA with such nanoparticles-encapsulated gold vesicles, an enzyme-free ELISA with substantially enhanced sensitivity is established. To optimize the signal amplification system and thus enhance the detection sensitivity of associated enzyme-free ELISA, physicochemical properties of both nanoparticles and gold vesicles will be carefully controlled. To achieve the goal of this project, following research aims will be pursued: 1) Building the nanoparticles based signal amplification system; 2) Establishing the enzyme-free ELISA; and 3) Applying the enzyme-free ELISA to detecting human blood samples spiked with biomarker standards. The signal amplification technique is expected to impact the general field of in-vitro diagnostics and find a broad range of applications in biomedicine. This project will benefit the engagement of graduate and undergraduate students, especially women and minorities, into research. The research will also be integrated into outreach activities for K-12 students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) is broadly recognized as an accessible technology for medical diagnostics since it can be performed by less-trained personnel with an inexpensive spectrophotometer. While ELISA and its variations are widely used for clinical diagnostics and in research laboratories, their limit of detection has not been substantially improved in recent years, which inhibits many critical applications. In conventional ELISA, the detection signal (mostly colorimetric signal) is generated by enzyme-catalyzed reactions. Therefore, the detection sensitivity of conventional ELISA is largely limited by the catalytic activity of enzymes.

In this project, we proposed to develop a novel enzyme-free signal amplification paradigm which breaks the intrinsic limitations of enzymes for ELISA technology. Specifically, enzyme-mimicking nanoparticles (i.e., enzyme mimics)-loaded carrier is employed as an alternative to enzyme for ELISA. Due to collective contributions from multiple enzyme mimics on a single carrier, the enzyme mimics-carrier complex could catalyze colorimetric reaction at a rate much higher than that an enzyme can achieve, providing much stronger color signal and thus substantially improved sensitivity for ELISA.

The most significant fundamental outcome of this project is that we have been able to gain fundamental understanding on catalytic activity of peroxidase (a type of enzyme commonly used in ELISA)-mimicking nanoparticles (i.e., peroxidase mimics). As alternatives to natural peroxidases, peroxidase mimics made of inorganic nanoparticles have been actively developed in recent years for biosensing applications. Nevertheless, there is a lack of fundamental study about the catalytic activity of peroxidase mimics. In this research, we have carefully investigated the structure-property relationship of peroxidase mimics from both experimental and theoretical angles. For example, in one study, we have demonstrated, for the first time, strain effect in catalytic activity of peroxidase mimics using palladium nanocrystals as a model system. In another study, we have systematically investigated the impact of particle size of peroxidase mimics in determining their catalytic activities as well as their performance in immunoassays, where palladium-iridium nanoparticles were chosen as a type of model peroxidase mimics.

In technical aspect of the outcomes, we have substantially improved the sensitivity of ELISA by using peroxidase mimics and peroxidase mimics-carrier complex as labels. For instance, we found that iridium nanoparticle is the most catalytically active peroxidase mimic among all platinum-group metal nanoparticles. The iridium nanoparticles as labels were successfully applied to ELISA, which was much more sensitive than conventional enzyme-based ELISA in detecting carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA, a cancer biomarker). In a recent study, we have fabricated iridium nanoparticles-decorated tungsten suboxide (WO2.72) nanorod complex. A single WO2.72 nanorod as a carrier could be loaded with multiple iridium nanoparticles. The Ir nanoparticles-WO2.72 nanorod as label was applied to ELISA of CEA that achieved an ultralow detection limit, hundreds of times lower than conventional enzyme-based ELISA.

This research contributed to an improved understanding of enzyme mimics and technical advancement of ELISA technology. The project also provided training for graduate and undergraduate students as well as high school students in the STEM disciplines.

 


Last Modified: 12/25/2022
Modified by: Xiaohu Xia
